headline: ChatGPT: Everything you need to know about the AI-powered chatbot
summary: ChatGPT, OpenAI’s text-generating AI chatbot, has taken the world by storm since its launch in November 2022. What started as a tool to hyper-charge productivity through writing essays and code with short text prompts has evolved into a behemoth used by more than 92% of Fortune 500 companies. That growth has propelled OpenAI itself into becoming one of the most-hyped companies in recent memory. And its latest partnership with Apple for its upcoming generative AI offering, Apple Intelligence, has

headline: Copilot Vision, Microsoft's AI tool that can read your screen, launches in preview
summary: Microsoft's AI can now read your screen — or rather, the websites you're browsing. On Thursday, the company began rolling out a limited, U.S.-only preview of Copilot Vision, a tool that can understand and respond to questions about sites you're visiting using Microsoft Edge. Gated behind Copilot Labs, an opt-in program for experimental AI capabilities, Copilot Vision can analyze text and images on web pages to answer queries like “What’s the recipe for this lasagna?" headline: Analysis-Vodafone-Three merger approval marks UK antitrust shift
summary: Britain's decision to allow two of its four mobile networks to merge is the first big sign that regulators have taken on board the government's wish for them to prioritise economic growth and infrastructure investment over lower consumer prices.  The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) antitrust regulator cleared the $19 billion Vodafone-Three UK deal on Thursday after it accepted the companies' argument that better networks would drive competition and be good for the economy.  The approval comes 18 months after the CMA infuriated Microsoft by blocking its $69 billion Activision Blizzard deal outright over concerns about competition in the nascent cloud gaming market.

raw.headline: Analysis-Vodafone-Three merger approval marks UK antitrust shift
raw.summary: Britain's decision to allow two of its four mobile networks to merge is the first big sign that regulators have taken on board the government's wish for them to prioritise economic growth and infrastructure investment over lower consumer prices.  The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) antitrust regulator cleared the $19 billion Vodafone-Three UK deal on Thursday after it accepted the companies' argument that better networks would drive competition and be good for the economy.  The approval comes 18 months after the CMA infuriated Microsoft by blocking its $69 billion Activision Blizzard deal outright over concerns about competition in the nascent cloud gaming market.

headline: How To Earn $500 A Month From Microsoft Stock
summary: Microsoft Corporation (NASDAQ:MSFT) shares closed higher on Wednesday. Microsoft announced Tuesday that its board of directors declared a quarterly dividend of 83 cents per share, which is payable March 13, 2025, to shareholders of record on Feb. 20, 2025. With the recent buzz around Microsoft, some investors may be eyeing potential gains from the company's dividends, too. As of now, Microsoft offers an annual dividend yield of 0.76%. That’s a quarterly dividend amount of 83 cents per share ($3.

headline: Needham predicts Roku will be acquired for ‘big premium’ in 2025
summary: Needham analyst Laura Martin keeps a Buy rating on Roku (ROKU) with a $100 price target after Walmart (WMT) closed its $2.3B acquisition of Vizio. Walmart will now “fast follow” Amazon (AMZN) and create a better retail media network by tying Vizio’s connected TV ads to Walmart’s online and offline sales, the analyst tells investors in a research note. headline: 1 AI Stock to Buy Before It Jumps 15%, According to a Certain Wall Street Analyst
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) has been a hot trend for investors all year, and as a result, popular AI stocks have been on a tear.  Meanwhile, Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) -- which is heavily invested in AI through its stake in ChatGPT's parent, OpenAI -- has risen a poky 14.7%.  The analyst in question is Citibank's co-head of U.S. software equity research, Tyler Radke, who has been following Microsoft since 2021.
